text: Hello. Running some code of mine with `@time` , I get :`7821.040149 seconds (23.55 G allocations: 1.653 TiB, 21.28% gc time)` . The code essentially consists in iterating over lots of small vectors constructed during the runtime. There is no big data that is read from disk or streamed from outside. The 1.6TiB makes me think I allocate way too much. How extreme are those numbers?

text: How small is small? You might be able to improve performance by a lot by using StaticArrays.jl

text: If small is less than about 100, I would give StaticArrays.jl a go

text: Maybe `SizedArray` s make sense, then
Say I have a diagonal matrix M and vectors u,v: does the product `u'*M*v` allocate a vector? Would it be better to have a custom routine to do the computation (since no allocation is needed here) ?

text: It will allocate, but not if you use `dot`

text: Dot is that custom function
And yeah, StaticArrays.jl require you to have a statically known size. Sometimes this can be worked around by using a function barrier

elements.text: And yeah, StaticArrays.jl require you to have a statically known size. Sometimes this can be worked around by using a function barrier

text: are you using mutating functions? even with lots of small vectors, it may be possible to preallocate your working memory

text:
`dot` with diagonal matrix will dispatch to
```dot(x::AbstractVector, D::Diagonal, y::AbstractVector) = _mapreduce_prod(dot, x, D, y)```

text:
Find it using
```let a = randn(2), B = Diagonal(randn(2))
           @edit dot(a,B,a)
end```

text: there is no `three_way_dot(x,y,z)` and I guess `dot(x,dot(y,z))` allocates
three argument dot exists though?
it's just `dot(a,b,c)`

the point of `Diagonal` is precisely do represent a diagonal matrix by just storing its diagonal

```Diagonal(V::AbstractVector)               
                                          
Construct a matrix with V as its diagonal.```

elements.text: is precisely do represent a diagonal matrix by just storing its diagonal

text: the reason for it being its own type is precisely to allow specialization based on the type
